awd_titl_txt: Conference/Workshop: Shaping Future STS Research on Societal Science Issues
awd_abstract_narration:
This conference grant will bring Science, Technology and Society (STS) scholars together to address equitable consequences of current contemporary societal science issues, questions, and challenges.  Outcomes will be distributed through a broadly shared report to the STS research community.  A set of readings that translate cutting edge STS research into accessible and interesting articles for undergraduate students, and development of a master syllabus for teaching undergraduate courses on societal science issues will be developed.  These materials will be freely available and of interest to policy makers, citizens and educators. 

The workshop brings together senior STS scholars with an established track record of research along with newer STS scholars (graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, assistant professors) to help shape future STS research.  The workshop is organized around several topical areas: emerging public environmental problems, effective communication of science and its public understanding, governance, and possibilities for opening more policy options and broader democratic participation, environmental inequality and injustice, and how new socio-technologies and societal visionaries become integrated into existing systems.  Workshop participants will be recruited in each area of research to summarize what is known, open discussion of unanswered questions, and contribute to the report and pedagogical products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The U.S. NSF’s programs in Science and Technology Studies (STS) and Ethical and Responsible Research (ER2) sponsored a two-day workshop on research on global climate change and other environmental issues. The workshop was held 28-29 June at the University of Southern Indiana, Evansville, IN. Workshop participants came from several nations including the U.S., Canada, Brazil, UK, Germany, and Sweden. A total of 20 researchers (10 female, 10 male) participated in the workshop (three via zoom) along with two USI undergraduate students who assisted with workshop logistics. Ten participants were senior level scholars (associate professors and above) and ten were junior level (assistant professor or below). Junior level participants included one postdoctoral fellow, four graduate students, and one non-governmental organization member.

Presentations and discussion of future research needs focused on six topics. Session one addressed the utility of constructivist STS approaches to climate change and contributions to our understanding of public communication of climate change and other environmental issues. Participants emphasized the need to maintain this theoretical approach to climate change and discussed specific areas where it provided the most utility. Session two addressed STS research on global climate change governance. Of particular interest in this session are the work of the IPCC as an international governance body and the challenges posed by global inequality and denialist ideologies for reaching international consensus. Session three focused specifically on matters of inequality and justice. Workshop participants emphasized the utility of STS and ER2 methodological approaches to public engagement in science for improving inclusivity in climate knowledge production and disentangling inequalities in climate change effects. Session four elaborated on current and future research on sociotechnical transitions in energy infrastructure, adaptation, and climate engineering. STS research can make significant contributions to understanding the social aspects of sociotechnical transitions such as in changing user practices, intervention of government, social aspects of necessary market adjustments, and broadening understanding of social dynamics of climate engineering. Session five focused on STS and ER2 research on climate change futures, sometimes referred to as futuring. Three key issues were raised: 1) does STS and ER2 currently hold sufficient theory to address the future of climate change emission reduction and adaptation? 2) how does one handle the tension in STS and ER2 research between providing a critical voice to scientific and technological work while also advocating specific pathways to more workable and egalitarian futures? 3) what are limitations to STS and ER2 foregrounding traditionally dispossessed and disenfranchised voices through their research on social movements and similar activity? While answers to these questions were not resolved at the workshop, participants took away ideas for future research on these topics.

Session six and one of the working lunches focused on pedagogy. A key question that was discussed is how STS and ER2 researchers might develop improved materials and approaches for teaching about climate change and other environmental problems at the undergraduate level. One of the assignments for participants prior to the workshop was to write a short paper that translated their research into a form accessible to undergraduate students and the public. It was decided at the workshop to expand upon this assignment and publish an open access collection of readings on climate change. This product from the workshop was published in 2024 (Baker, Law, Vardy, and Zehr, Climate, Science and Society: A Primer, Routledge) consisting of 37 chapters organized across eleven parts. NSF and small contributions from the University of Southern Indiana and Sonoma State University enabled the publication of it as “open access” so that students and anyone else worldwide might download and read it for free.

Additional products from the workshop included a final report sent to NSF, workshop participants, and others who request it and the development of a master syllabus for teaching about global climate change and other environmental issues in undergraduate classes.
